commit_message:
Fixed attach volume for EMC SMI-S iSCSI driver

This problem was encountered during Grizzly RC1 testing.  The driver
didn't find the correct target IQN.  As a result, Nova couldn't find
the matching path in /dev/disk/by-path and therefore detached the volume.

Change-Id: I8bcf6d9896b9d445f6376ecc3a5695be46507663
Fixes: bug #1157912

[{'created': '2013-03-22 16:57:07.000000000', 'message': 'Rename trust extension.

Change trust extension from RH-TRUST to OS-TRUST so that the namespace
being used is for OpenStack, as opposed to a contributing company.  This
is also more consistent with namespacing used in other OpenStack APIs.

Some additional discussion about this is in this thread:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-March/006876.html

Change-Id: I0fd869abe0f527c899808a4dde19dbd1fb6f32cd
'}]
commit_message:
Rename trust extension.

Change trust extension from RH-TRUST to OS-TRUST so that the namespace
being used is for OpenStack, as opposed to a contributing company.  This
is also more consistent with namespacing used in other OpenStack APIs.

Some additional discussion about this is in this thread:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-March/006876.html

Change-Id: I0fd869abe0f527c899808a4dde19dbd1fb6f32cd

[{'created': '2013-03-22 19:15:42.000000000', 'message': "py2.6 doesn't support TextTestRunner resultclass

Updates tools/colorizer to account for the fact that Python
2.6 doesn't support resultclass.

This fixes issue in trying to use run_tests.sh on distributions
which use python 2.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1158940.

Change-Id: I763cd9c7a4b5ec5baaad3a3d9ee96e6e3cd13b3e
"}, {'created': '2013-03-22 19:47:36.000000000', 'message': "Reset ec2 image cache between S3 tests.

We recently introduced EC2 image caching in 2865a76.

On some python 2.6 distros I'm now seeing nova.tests.image.test_s3
failures caused by test ordering issues. Tests appear to reuse
IDs and this can cause issue if we don't clear the cache in tearDown.

Fixes LP Bug #1158935.

Change-Id: I763cd9c7a4b5ec5baaad3a3d9ee96e6e3cd13b3e
"}, {'created': '2013-03-22 19:53:11.000000000', 'message': "py2.6 doesn't support TextTestRunner resultclass

Updates tools/colorizer to account for the fact that Python
2.6 doesn't support resultclass.

This fixes issue in trying to use run_tests.sh on distributions
which use python 2.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1158940

Change-Id: I763cd9c7a4b5ec5baaad3a3d9ee96e6e3cd13b3e
"}]
commit_message:
py2.6 doesn't support TextTestRunner resultclass

Updates tools/colorizer to account for the fact that Python
2.6 doesn't support resultclass.

This fixes issue in trying to use run_tests.sh on distributions
which use python 2.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1158940

Change-Id: I763cd9c7a4b5ec5baaad3a3d9ee96e6e3cd13b3e

commit_message:
Snapshot reservation sync calls wrong resource.

The snapshot reservations code isn't calling the
correct resource on sync (it's calling volumes).  There's
also some problems with the logic being used on the delete/clean up
that are fixed here as well.

Fixes bug: 1157506
Fixes bug: 1157982

Change-Id: I91327b8043ab63aa35ea8a91b6de544bf5bf6c61

[{'created': '2013-03-22 15:14:28.000000000', 'message': 'Remove skips in volume types tests.

This commit removes the skips from test_volume_types_extra_specs_negative
for bugs that have been marked as fixed. However, the XML client class was
not written to accept the bad input for the negative tests. So the XML
client is modified to accept this input. Additionally, the skip in
test_volume_types_negative.py was removed as well.

(cherry picked from commit c8aba03038ab31bda9f3595c3fa978b469ce8d97)

Change-Id: I45090c29a4115c205b656777e57a940a7de7dbf5
'}]
commit_message:
Remove skips in volume types tests.

This commit removes the skips from test_volume_types_extra_specs_negative
for bugs that have been marked as fixed. However, the XML client class was
not written to accept the bad input for the negative tests. So the XML
client is modified to accept this input. Additionally, the skip in
test_volume_types_negative.py was removed as well.

(cherry picked from commit c8aba03038ab31bda9f3595c3fa978b469ce8d97)

Change-Id: I45090c29a4115c205b656777e57a940a7de7dbf5

commit_message:
Add script for updating requirements

This is a hacky little script for pulling all of the requirements
from each project into a consolidate pair of pip-requires and
test-requires files.

The output of this can't be passed to 'pip install -r' without
some further sanitation to clean up duplicates.

Change-Id: I47159f744086dc1de1b9fa07ef4cc5a0f85087b0

Warn about shared storage and image cache manager

Warn operators to disable the image cache manager when using
shared storage in Folsom.

See bug 1155391 for details.

commit_message:
Fix javelin image name setup

Needed to handle an arbitrary cirros image release as devstack-gate
uses the current (target) release and not the one used in the base
DevStack.

Change-Id: I202976fb1669d09648572f4666111442e9967be4

commit_message:
Clean up stack.sh config

* Clean up interactive configuration
* Complete moving initialization of service-specific varialbes into the
  service lib/* files.

commit_message:
Add flake8.

flake8 is the new state-of-the-art for pep8/pyflakes processing. It is
pluggable and configurable and is the basis for the new version of hacking.py.

Change-Id: I7896568836675ae379c14865b5d04c7bcdbd99e2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-21 19:14:14.000000000', 'message': 'Create conductor API early in compute manager.

The compute virt API uses the conductor API instance on the compute
manager.  Create the conductor API instance before creating the virt API
instance and passing it down to the virt driver.  This prevents the
possibility of code trying to use the conductor API before it has been
initialized.

Fix bug 1156490.

Change-Id: I19684f24d590201d135336107425c2be2f74c83e
'}, {'created': '2013-03-22 14:20:23.000000000', 'message': "Initialize compute manager before loading driver.

The compute virt API uses the conductor API instance on the compute
manager.  Make sure the compute manager has been fully initialized
before loading the driver and passing it the virtapi instance.  This
prevents the possibility of the driver calling back into the compute
manager and using something not initialized yet, such as the conductor
API in the case of this bug.

This patch also moves initialization of a member variable up above
super(), where the rest of the initialization is.  There doesn't appear
to be a reason for needing to have it at the end.

Fix bug 1156490.

Change-Id: I19684f24d590201d135336107425c2be2f74c83e
"}]
commit_message:
Initialize compute manager before loading driver.

The compute virt API uses the conductor API instance on the compute
manager.  Make sure the compute manager has been fully initialized
before loading the driver and passing it the virtapi instance.  This
prevents the possibility of the driver calling back into the compute
manager and using something not initialized yet, such as the conductor
API in the case of this bug.

This patch also moves initialization of a member variable up above
super(), where the rest of the initialization is.  There doesn't appear
to be a reason for needing to have it at the end.

Fix bug 1156490.

Change-Id: I19684f24d590201d135336107425c2be2f74c83e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-19 21:57:43.000000000', 'message': 'pin pep8 to an exact version

prior to an aggreed pinning of pep8 in grizzly we ended up with a
rediculous amount of code churn on minor pep8 bumps accross the
projects. It was seen as a huge step forward to pin this to a version
for a release.

We need to not regress this and reintroduce the code churn on pep8
bumps happening upstream, as every single one of them typically
requires a code change on our behalf to integrate. We should take
a single hit at the beginning of a release cycle to the newest pep8
version, and keep it pinned at that till the next release.

Change-Id: I957e98f7e82156a26c86ee5d55c6993486070404
'}]
commit_message:
pin pep8 to an exact version

prior to an aggreed pinning of pep8 in grizzly we ended up with a
rediculous amount of code churn on minor pep8 bumps accross the
projects. It was seen as a huge step forward to pin this to a version
for a release.

We need to not regress this and reintroduce the code churn on pep8
bumps happening upstream, as every single one of them typically
requires a code change on our behalf to integrate. We should take
a single hit at the beginning of a release cycle to the newest pep8
version, and keep it pinned at that till the next release.

Change-Id: I957e98f7e82156a26c86ee5d55c6993486070404

commit_message:
Fetch volume_types by uuid and not by name in v2

This was left over from the UUID switch. Looking up volume_types by name
is deprecated in v1 and removed in v2.

Fixes: bug #1087817
Change-Id: I02cc035565f9496cd5af228c55ced5cafef2ad81

commit_message:
lockutils: add a failing unit test

Add a unit test which fails because of #1107950 - in this case,
lockutils is deleting the lock directory every time the lock is dropped
even though another process might have acquired a lock using that
directory.

Change-Id: Ic82409f9462e570bc102ab469334c53aafc6d7ac

I can't say I understand any of this, really ... but if

1) The Havana server just uses the copy of the context that is never going away, it will work with Grizzly, Havana and later versions

2) The Havana client no longer sends a copy of the context which was never used by Grizzly servers, then there's no impact on compat

The commit message, bug report and inline comment don't really explain any of this very well ... but if I squint, it looks like that's that's what the code is doing"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-03-22 14:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Yes, Mark, that summarizes what this patch should do.

Havana is now able to understand the 'msg' kwarg as a list or a scalar (line 695 patched code). It still sends it as a list for Grizzly compatibility.  Grizzly gets context from this list - i.e. line 300 in the base patch.  In the I release, the 'msg' kwarg can be sent simply as a scalar as Havana will understand that (Grizzly will not) per the addition at line 298."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-03-22 16:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2013-03-19 02:15:31.000000000', 'message': "Eliminate multiple contexts in zmq call()

Because we need compatibility with Grizzly (N-1 support), this should be
reduced to two copies for Havana, before stripping down to a singular
copy for I.

The '-reply' request has its context key removed, with the
msg option maintaining one extra copy of context until I.
A TODO has been entered to clean this up following the Havana release.

This fix eliminates an extra JSON double-deserialization routine.
The double-serialization of context is still performed for Grizzly
compatibility.

fixes bug 1156956

commit_message:
Eliminate multiple contexts in zmq call()

Because we need compatibility with Grizzly (N-1 support), this should be
reduced to two copies for Havana, before stripping down to a singular
copy for I.

The '-reply' request has its context key removed, with the
msg option maintaining one extra copy of context until I.
A TODO has been entered to clean this up following the Havana release.

This fix eliminates an extra JSON double-deserialization routine.
The double-serialization of context is still performed for Grizzly
compatibility.

fixes bug 1156956

Change-Id: I071e382ec9c7e0df3794fe9ca574a5722f8910a6

Please comment on the approach used.

The idea is to get better logging information when an exception is raised during an rpc call.

It adds a decorator and decorates all rpc call methods in all implementations.

The decorator logs the exception, adding the rpc method called, and the 'topic' (if available), then re-raises the exception."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-03-05 06:54:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(9 inline comments)

How does this compare to e.g. I0e831ddcc43ffea78aae1fb5e46c5037c461b2a1 where we're moving away from the RPC layer logging everything because exceptions that pass through RPC aren't always errors ... this patch seems to undo that, no?

Looks like you should have three independent patches - 1) the logging changes, 2) the timeout/tuple raise in zmq and 3) random cleanups"}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-03-05 10:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-05 10:40:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Improves Logging for for rpc method timeouts

This patch moves the traceback for an rpc timeout from inside an
iterator, which gave a useless traceback, into the main flow of the
program.

It also adds the rpc method being called and the topic used to the
exception's message.

When the caller logs the message higher up the stack, the log
information and traceback will be more useful.

Finally it removes the timeout logging in the amqp.py module, in the
spirit of bug #1137994 and https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23295/

Works towards: bug #1148516

Change-Id: I29a3b1b97c6114c4479e2b71c1257c4d72131535

commit_message:
Enable message envelope.

Grizzly had the ability to receive messages with an envelope, but did
not send them.  Now update the code to send them.

Change-Id: I73aad7697cf83ad4aabb3c2058b7cc4f53f783c2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-22 10:36:31.000000000', 'message': "lockutils: improve the external locks test

Use a separate directory for the lockutils external locks and for the
test's flocks which are used to check that serialization is actually
occurring. By using the same directory, we can't test the code in
lockutils which auto-creates this directory because the dir gets
deleted by a process by lockutils cleanup while another directory
is using it for flocks.

Also, assume the the handles directory has been created in the parent
rather than having each child attempt to create it.

Related, add a try/finally block so that when a child process throws an
exception it immediately exits rather than deleting the temporary
directories created by the parent.

Change-Id: I32d7e8e05fb3f22cf38fa586f8bc97646c83f182
"}]
commit_message:
lockutils: improve the external locks test

Use a separate directory for the lockutils external locks and for the
test's flocks which are used to check that serialization is actually
occurring. By using the same directory, we can't test the code in
lockutils which auto-creates this directory because the dir gets
deleted by a process by lockutils cleanup while another directory
is using it for flocks.

Also, assume the the handles directory has been created in the parent
rather than having each child attempt to create it.

Related, add a try/finally block so that when a child process throws an
exception it immediately exits rather than deleting the temporary
directories created by the parent.

Change-Id: I32d7e8e05fb3f22cf38fa586f8bc97646c83f182

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-22 07:37:04.000000000', 'message': "Gracefully handle errors in logging config files

Fixes bug #1154245

If the parameter to the --log-config option cannot be loaded by the
logging.config.fileConfig() function, you get an exception like this
raised:

  NoSectionError: No section: 'formatters'

which doesn't do much to help users understand the error.

Improve the situation by wrapping the error in a custom exception type
giving this:

 LogConfigError: Error loading logging config /etc/logging.conf: No section: 'formatters'

Also add some tests to check we raise this error under the most common
failure conditions.

Change-Id: I6ad2eb4867213b6356ce43d75da50218d1b498f6
"}]
commit_message:
Gracefully handle errors in logging config files

Fixes bug #1154245

If the parameter to the --log-config option cannot be loaded by the
logging.config.fileConfig() function, you get an exception like this
raised:

  NoSectionError: No section: 'formatters'

which doesn't do much to help users understand the error.

Improve the situation by wrapping the error in a custom exception type
giving this:

 LogConfigError: Error loading logging config /etc/logging.conf: No section: 'formatters'

Also add some tests to check we raise this error under the most common
failure conditions.

Change-Id: I6ad2eb4867213b6356ce43d75da50218d1b498f6

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-14 23:23:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

What advantage does this offer over the account quota mechanism introduced in commit 28c75db?"}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2013-03-15 01:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

To consider the eventual consistency, the container-updater update container data to account-server asynchronously, this commit not limit the storage usage of account but container. By limiting the container_usage and container_count, the Quota can limit the total storage usage of an account and more accurate.

This commit implemented a more agile quota policy.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-16 19:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Alright, so your goal here is quotas that take effect more quickly. That is, in order to limit how much a user can go over-quota due to the effect of eventual consistency, you've put quotas on the number and size of containers. This is not an unreasonable goal.

There are some definite problems with the implementation, though.

First, the middleware is named "quota". We've already got two middlewares named "account_quotas" and "container_quotas". If this were to get merged, Swift would have "quota", "account_quotas", and "container_quotas", which is very confusing. Either merge those into this or merge this into those.

Second, this is based on a static JSON file to define the quota levels, but there's no refreshing of the contents. Therefore, a change in the quota levels requires a restart of the proxy servers.

Third, having number-of-container and container-size restrictions is not particularly user-friendly. If you give my account a limit of 10 GB and 10 containers, then I can't upload a 2 GB file even though my total allowed storage is 10 GB.'}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2013-03-17 02:14:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-17 02:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-swift-pep8/1876 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-swift-docs/1708 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-swift-python26/1956 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-swift-python27/1958 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/9262 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/14608 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/24406/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/8978 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2013-03-17 03:41:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Firstly, I think it is better to create a discussion or bug report to discuss how to combine these quota middleware after merge this patch. I prefer remove container-quotas and account-quotas, because they are not friendly with the production environment. Users will complain the inconsistency of account-quotas, administrators will complain the security and inconvenience of container-quotas. On the other hand, the Quota implemented a security(only reseller_admin can set the quota-level metadata), agile(precise_mode to switch the need of performance or accuracy) and easy-management(based on level policy) storage quotas.

Secondly, to consider the change of quota policy is not frequently, I think there is no need to detect the change of quota.json and reload it to memery.

Thirdly, because of the eventual consistency?the quota of account is valueless but soft limit. In my view, the reseller of object storage should hide the account level to users.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-21 22:18:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

If you'd like to start a discussion on what Swift quotas should look like, please do so. I recommend either creating a Launchpad bug or a post on the openstack-dev mailing list; please don't make a blueprint since participants on blueprints don't get update emails (IIRC).

Currently, though, Swift has two complementary quota middlewares. This new middleware overlaps with both of the existing ones in confusing ways. Any patch that puts this middleware in will have to also address what to do with the two existing middlewares."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:21:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Alex please feel free to come over on the next #openstack-swift meeting https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings#Swift_team_meeting so we can discuss this further of what are missing for you in the current quotas implementation."}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2013-03-22 16:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2013-03-22 16:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Need Discussions'}]

commit_message:
Quota

Add a new middleware fot storage quota.
The policy of Quota is based on the quota level. Only the reseller admin can
assign the quota level by adding 'X-Account-Meta-Quota-Level: level' to
account metadata. The Quota read the detail policy from quota.json and
handle specific requests.

Change-Id: I5bfa8cd9816ba561899874517785681f183c6518

Fix bug 1155215

[{'created': '2013-03-12 22:11:56.000000000', 'message': "End compat for keystone.middleware.auth_token

During grizzly, we supported both keystone.middleware.auth_token (folsom
default) and keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token (grizzly default);
this patch ends support for that backward compatibility.

This forces users to upgrade their configuration to refer directly to
the latest middleware, which must now be installed anyway (via
keystoneclient).

When configuring the middleware for inclusion in (for example)
nova's pipeline, you used to do:

  [filter:auth_token]
  paste.filter_factory = keystone.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory

Which must now be updated to:

  [filter:auth_token]
  paste.filter_factory = keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory

Fixes bug 1143998.

Change-Id: I4b116a81ad2239fd9941101d40ba3fdac7b97f11

commit_message:
End compat for keystone.middleware.auth_token

During grizzly, we supported both keystone.middleware.auth_token (folsom
default) and keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token (grizzly default);
this patch ends support for that backward compatibility.

This forces users to upgrade their configuration to refer directly to
the latest middleware, which must now be installed anyway (via
keystoneclient).

When configuring the middleware for inclusion in (for example)
nova's pipeline, you used to do:

  [filter:auth_token]
  paste.filter_factory = keystone.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory

Which must now be updated to:

  [filter:auth_token]
  paste.filter_factory = keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory

Fixes bug 1143998.

DocImpact - see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24253/

Change-Id: I4b116a81ad2239fd9941101d40ba3fdac7b97f11

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-21 23:03:07.000000000', 'message': "translate cinder BadRequest exception

if we attempt to create a volume with values that are invalid (like
a non numeric value for size) we properly get a BadRequest returned
from cinder. However we inproperly pass that cinderclient exception
all the way to the top of the request process, causing a stack trace
to appear in the logs because this is an exception type Nova doesn't
understand.

This situation is triggered by Tempest on every run, and while the
return is successful, the stack trace might spook people.

Fix this by increasing the scope of the existing
_reraise_translated_volume_exception() method. Longer term it would
make sense to have a decorator that handles all possible exceptions
we'd expect from cinder client and turn them into Nova exceptions.

This reduces the number of stack traces in nova-api by 6 on a
successful Tempest run.

Fixes bug #1158505

Step towards blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: Ifcfbd5eb11fe9f038f648ca5291499290b7126b1
"}, {'created': '2013-03-22 14:25:24.000000000', 'message': "translate cinder BadRequest exception

if we attempt to create a volume with values that are invalid (like
a non numeric value for size) we properly get a BadRequest returned
from cinder. However we inproperly pass that cinderclient exception
all the way to the top of the request process, causing a stack trace
to appear in the logs because this is an exception type Nova doesn't
understand.

This situation is triggered by Tempest on every run, and while the
return is successful, the stack trace might spook people.

Fix this by increasing the scope of the existing
_reraise_translated_volume_exception() method. Longer term it would
make sense to have a decorator that handles all possible exceptions
we'd expect from cinder client and turn them into Nova exceptions.

This reduces the number of stack traces in nova-api by 6 on a
successful Tempest run.

Fixes bug #1158505

Step towards blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: Ifcfbd5eb11fe9f038f648ca5291499290b7126b1
"}]
commit_message:
translate cinder BadRequest exception

if we attempt to create a volume with values that are invalid (like
a non numeric value for size) we properly get a BadRequest returned
from cinder. However we inproperly pass that cinderclient exception
all the way to the top of the request process, causing a stack trace
to appear in the logs because this is an exception type Nova doesn't
understand.

This situation is triggered by Tempest on every run, and while the
return is successful, the stack trace might spook people.

Fix this by increasing the scope of the existing
_reraise_translated_volume_exception() method. Longer term it would
make sense to have a decorator that handles all possible exceptions
we'd expect from cinder client and turn them into Nova exceptions.

This reduces the number of stack traces in nova-api by 6 on a
successful Tempest run.

Fixes bug #1158505

Step towards blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: Ifcfbd5eb11fe9f038f648ca5291499290b7126b1

<link linkend="configuring-migrations">live migration</link>

commit_message:
Updates to use 1.7.2 to build openstack-install.

Patchset resolves the two broken links at:
<link linkend="ch_cells">Cells</link>
<link linkend="configuring-migrations">live migration</link>
by converting them to link xlink:href and doing a relative
link to the Compute Admin manual HTML file that is output.
This way, the build works and the user can still click to
get the needed information.

Change-Id: I44dfc5965e78568c172c95b86f71324fb3f2ff7c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-21 10:59:44.000000000', 'message': 'CoraidDriver: typo in _login exception handler

In cinder/volume/drivers/coraid.py, _login method, if login is
unsuccessful, we try to get the message from an undefined
object "response". Instead we should be getting it from "reply".

- errmsg = response.get('message', '')
+ errmsg = reply.get('message', '')

Fixes bug 1157499

Change-Id: Ifd047ced6b40f49881e81d4e73189d9bd216c903
'}]
commit_message:
CoraidDriver: typo in _login exception handler

In cinder/volume/drivers/coraid.py, _login method, if login is
unsuccessful, we try to get the message from an undefined
object "response". Instead we should be getting it from "reply".

- errmsg = response.get('message', '')
+ errmsg = reply.get('message', '')

Fixes bug 1157499

Change-Id: Ifd047ced6b40f49881e81d4e73189d9bd216c903

commit_message:
CoraidDriver: do not call login from __init__

We should not call _login from the driver's __init__.
If the ESM is down, the constructor will fail.

- self._login()

Fixes bug 1157500

Change-Id: Ie57fbb6d3704d270a81cd9eb056d7988989da1f8

Use upstream git repository for merciless

There's no need to use mine, it's better to track upstream until a new
vresion of Ming is released.

Change-Id: Id0c0b30c10bb8241f6b9f42907eb508ed3891228
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

Change-Id: I2d197320b61f44d1104ed0342a6b5b70f673468a
'}, {'created': '2013-03-21 18:10:50.000000000', 'message': 'Extend param2id() to work with uuids

commit_message:
Extend param2id() to work with uuids

Add uuid support to param2id() to allow commands including
cinder-manage volume delete to work with uuid style volumd ids

Fixes bug #1158409

Change-Id: I2d197320b61f44d1104ed0342a6b5b70f673468a

commit_message:
Change arguments to volume_detach()

Most compute API calls accept an instance object.  To be compatible with
cells, volume_detach() should as well.  Also change it to accept the
volume object, instead of just a volume ID.  This lets us proxy the
volume object to child cells a bit more easily.

This removes 2 skipTests that we have related to volumes and cells.

Fixes bug 1157408

There was also a check that if instance_get_by_uuid() returned no
instance, it VolumeUnattached should be raised.  However, this check
would never work as InstanceNotFound would have been raised.  This
patch also corrects that.

Change-Id: Ide35ad5d8e147f6bd21b5840b901363dab0eae38

commit_message:
Fixed pep8 errors in test directory.

Files test_swiftclient.py and utils.py had all pep8 errors
fixed.

Also added tests directory to tox.ini file, so that
pep8 would monitor tests directory by default.

Change-Id: Ie7efe204ff8243f473a8ec85250d2d7ce5316c3d

commit_message:
Revert "Remove skips in volume types tests."

This reverts commit c8aba03038ab31bda9f3595c3fa978b469ce8d97

Unfortunately, although the fix was merged to Cinder recently that addressed the need for the skip, it wasn't merged until after the cut for RC1.  So.. now we can't backport to milestone-proposed as long as these tests are enabled until everything catches up.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-21 17:33:50.000000000', 'message': "Make entry point strings readable

I can't stand the way pep8 E126 wants continued strings to line up vertically,
it totally destroys the readability and visual indication of the beginning of
a string; the only way to KNOW (without knowing what the content of the string
is supposed to represent) is to find the comma at the end of the line and work
backwards.

This is a proposal to work around the pep8 E126 requirement by wrapping all of
the entry-point strings in parens to allow indentation of the continuation
lines.  Other suggestions to restore readability to these lists of long strings
are welcome.

Apparently the presence of '+' in this case is harmless for py27 at least. I
left them because they were already there.

Are there any objections to completing the remaining entry point strings?

Change-Id: I2593de7d6c058322101bc68636317cdba29fe664
"}, {'created': '2013-03-22 00:49:47.000000000', 'message': 'Make entry point strings readable

PEP8 E126 wants continued strings to line up vertically, totally destroying the
readability and visual indication of the beginning of a string in a list

* Ignore PEP8 E126 in order to indent the entry point strings in a readable manner.
* Sort the enrty point command strings by object then verb.

Change-Id: I2593de7d6c058322101bc68636317cdba29fe664
'}, {'created': '2013-03-22 02:46:14.000000000', 'message': 'Make entry point strings readable

PEP8 E126 wants continued strings to line up vertically, totally destroying the
readability and visual indication of the beginning of a string in a list

* Ignore PEP8 E126 in order to indent the entry point strings in a readable manner.
* Sort the enrty point command strings by object then verb.

Change-Id: I2593de7d6c058322101bc68636317cdba29fe664
'}, {'created': '2013-03-22 02:51:42.000000000', 'message': 'Make entry point strings readable

PEP8 E126 wants continued strings to line up vertically, totally destroying the
readability and visual indication of the beginning of a string in a list

* Ignore PEP8 E126 in order to indent the entry point strings in a readable manner.
* Sort the enrty point command strings by object then verb.
* Bring other ignores from run_tests.sh to tox.ini

Change-Id: I2593de7d6c058322101bc68636317cdba29fe664
'}]
commit_message:
Make entry point strings readable

PEP8 E126 wants continued strings to line up vertically, totally destroying the
readability and visual indication of the beginning of a string in a list

* Ignore PEP8 E126 in order to indent the entry point strings in a readable manner.
* Sort the enrty point command strings by object then verb.
* Bring other ignores from run_tests.sh to tox.ini

Change-Id: I2593de7d6c058322101bc68636317cdba29fe664

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-22 04:04:55.000000000', 'message': 'Updates to OSAPI sizelimit middleware.

Updates the OSAPI sizelimit middleware so that we use avoid calling
len on a request body which could cause a really large request
to get buffered into memory.

Also updates the middleware to return HTTP 413 which is a more
correct error code in this case (previously it returned just 400).

Fixes LP Bug #1131857.

Change-Id: Iff6cb0c24bc21e5a1d5dd4cf29acb0b4ee221708
(cherry picked from commit 3fe81851bab39a1466d8744b372b5a287b4db93d)
'}]
commit_message:
Updates to OSAPI sizelimit middleware.

Updates the OSAPI sizelimit middleware so that we use avoid calling
len on a request body which could cause a really large request
to get buffered into memory.

Also updates the middleware to return HTTP 413 which is a more
correct error code in this case (previously it returned just 400).

Fixes LP Bug #1131857.

Change-Id: Iff6cb0c24bc21e5a1d5dd4cf29acb0b4ee221708
(cherry picked from commit 3fe81851bab39a1466d8744b372b5a287b4db93d)

commit_message:
Allows wsgi server kwargs to be given.

This fix allows someone using openstack.common.wsgi to pass
kwargs down to eventlet.wsgi.server when calling wsgi.run_server.

Fixes bug 1156930

Change-Id: Id35232f68ee40c5435e157a834fc94d4bbd04970

commit_message:
Fix Storwize/SVC LUN allocation with holes.

The Storwize/SVC driver should find the first unused LUN, but
continues searching, returning erroneous results.  Added 'break'
statement to fix.

Change-Id: Ibd95714e086a513a39fe9d20ffec57135dc5ec55
Fixes: bug 1157012
(cherry picked from commit e0878c86207d5ff5c2ebaa69eac454af545925ef)

last time we updated it.

Fixes bug #1157126

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-03-22 04:05:11.000000000', 'message': "Pull Oslo log fix to enable root logger initialization

Previous log module in Oslo doesn't initialize root logger, which results
in lacking of log message for non-openstack library (such as stevedore).
This patch pull latest log module from Oslo, which has recently merged a
change to enable root logger initialization.

Notice that this change also includes one log modules fix in Oslo which
'unignore' log_format setting.  As a result, one may experience log format
change when using devstack.  To get old log format back, simply assign
a NULL string (aka nothing) to 'log_format' configure option in cinder.conf.
For example, just append cinder.conf with one new line 'log_format = '.

Fix bug: # 1131322

Change-Id: I86396f15ca152512ce6d18d6d424a855b27f495e
(cherry picked from commit 2b66a382aae3e1c80342feb32549c427677d39c6)
"}]
commit_message:
Pull Oslo log fix to enable root logger initialization

Previous log module in Oslo doesn't initialize root logger, which results
in lacking of log message for non-openstack library (such as stevedore).
This patch pull latest log module from Oslo, which has recently merged a
change to enable root logger initialization.

Notice that this change also includes one log modules fix in Oslo which
'unignore' log_format setting.  As a result, one may experience log format
change when using devstack.  To get old log format back, simply assign
a NULL string (aka nothing) to 'log_format' configure option in cinder.conf.
For example, just append cinder.conf with one new line 'log_format = '.

Fix bug: # 1131322

Change-Id: I86396f15ca152512ce6d18d6d424a855b27f495e
(cherry picked from commit 2b66a382aae3e1c80342feb32549c427677d39c6)

commit_message:
Implement get_volume_stats in NFS driver

Use the already existing code (ie: _get_available_capacity) to
implement get_volume_stats in the nfs driver

Change the netapp nfs driver to use this new implementation
instead of the dumb one.

Fixes bug #1152501

Change-Id: Ie16d9628ba4b096c60966b4aa6192fbdcb9a4f20
(cherry picked from commit c47bf9bc3835d4399185376ac07920ef903d79e8)

commit_message:
Switch all uses of 422 response code to 400.

The 422 response is normally only for WebDAV, and these types of
errors should normally return a 400 code, HTTPBadRequest. This
commit goes through all the remaining 422 codes and changes them
to 400 responses.

Fixes bug 1153807

Change-Id: I9bf49643763c2cb0ac585641056c85a060152e36
(cherry picked from commit adb8ba7bff2bc4e2657cf84e9f061433ff947a73)

commit_message:
Fixes dettach volumes in Windows cinder plugin

The patch fixes issues when desassigning target to initiators
in the terminate_connection method. The method now takes
the right parameter coming from provider location.

Change-Id: I2ea1ac7f46e3a24a6493af8eba46a113126e1117
Fixes: bug #1153968
(cherry picked from commit 6de6cfebd4398c9912eb1683c91226d5d27cf7e4)
